{{short description|1718-1906 series of illustrated antiquarian papers on ancient buildings, sites, and artefacts}} {{Italic title}} [[File:Roman mosaics from Vetusta monumenta (Vol.1, 1826).jpg|thumb|Roman [[mosaic]]s from [[Wellow, Somerset]] near [[Bath, England]], double page spread in volume 1, in an 1826 reprint]] '''''Vetusta Monumenta''''' is the title of a published series of illustrated [[antiquary|antiquarian]] papers on ancient buildings, sites, and artefacts, mostly those of Britain, published at irregular intervals between 1718 and 1906 by the [[Society of Antiquaries of London]]. The [[Folio (printing)|folio]] sized papers, usually written by members of the society, were first published individually, and then later in collected volumes.<ref name="Harris">{{cite web|url=http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/makinghistory/recording-and-illustrating,444,AR.html|title=: Antiquaries in Britain, 1707–2007 - Recording and illustrating|last=Harris|first=Greg|work=Making History|publisher=Royal Academy of Arts|accessdate=24 November 2010}}</ref>
==Publication== The full title is ''Vetusta monumenta quae ad Rerum Britanicarum memoriam conservandam Societas Antiquariorum Londini sumptu suo edenda curavit'', but the volumes are normally simply cited as ''Vetusta Monumenta''. There were various reprints of both individual papers and collected volumes, and the plates were often published separately from the text. According to the HOLLIS database at [[Harvard]]: "The seven volumes are dated 1747, 1789, 1796, 1815, 1835, 1883 and 1906 (for the fourth part of vol.7). The plates for vol. 1 were published between 1718 and 1747; plates for vol. 2 were published between 1748 and 1789; plates for vol. 3 were published between 1790 and 1796; plates for vol. 4 were published between 1799 and 1815; plates for vol. 5 were published between 1816 and 1835; plates for vol. 6 were published between 1821 and 1885; plates for the four parts of vol. 7 were published between 1893 and 1906."<ref>[http://eresearch.lib.harvard.edu/V/T9H1EJI2QMR5XA1E97JX3K8YYF9GRUU5N3ISA1YINE3AHKKV3T-77390?func=quick-1 HOLLIS database at Harvard] (dynamic link - enter title)</ref>
The series began the same year that the society formalized its existence with the first minuted meeting on January 1, 1718, at the Mitre Tavern, [[Fleet Street]]; the society's main journal ''[[Archaeologia_(London)#Publications|Archaeologia]]'' did not begin publication until 1770. Members of the society received a free copy as each part was published.<ref>Harris, [http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/makinghistory/founding-the-society-of-antiquaries,449,AR.html ''Founding the Society of Antiquaries''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306034954/http://www.royalacademy.org.uk/exhibitions/makinghistory/founding-the-society-of-antiquaries,449,AR.html |date=March 6, 2012 }} and ''Recording and illustrating'', as above.</ref>
==Contents== The emphasis was on the large and detailed illustrations, initially high quality [[engravings]], which conveyed information on the subject matter in an accessible and economical way.<ref name="Nurse">{{cite web|title=The Embarkation of Henry VIII at Dover 1520|last=Nurse |first=Bernard (Librarian, RSA)|work=alecto historical editions|accessdate=23 November 2010|location=United Kingdom}}</ref> Each issue was usually developed from papers and research of the society, giving a text description accompanied by illustrated details it had commissioned. The assemblage of maps, site plans, and other detail was a novelty that found popular appeal.
The views in the series contained images of people and other means of conveying scale, providing the perspective of the interested visitor. These accompanied text descriptions for the sites, but provided additional information with high levels of detail and multiple or idealised viewpoints to simulate a well informed tour. Many of the plates show the setting, inset with exploded views, cross sections and other architectural details, or objects found at the site. Other figures were interspersed with the text, or taking up several full pages. Critics have compared this approach with contemporaneous works that included the subject as an attractively sketched scene, illustrations were not yet recognised as a valuable source of information. The book used the multiple and separate details to synthesise encyclopaedic surveys that typified the approach of the natural historians and antiquaries, what [[Barbara Maria Stafford]] has described as "cross-referencing material bits of distant reality".<ref name="Arnold1999">{{cite book|last=Arnold|first=Dana|title=The metropolis and its image: constructing identities for London, c. 1750-1950|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ke4X4HjHTi8C&pg=PA14|accessdate=23 November 2010|year=1999|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|isbn=978-0-631-21667-4|pages=14–16|chapter=Atheticizing the Ancestral City}}</ref>
An 1803 article on the [[Rosetta Stone]] was amongst the earliest published research.<ref>1803: "Has tabulas inscriptionem ... ad formam et modulum exemplaris inter spolia ex bello Aegyptiaco nuper reportati et in Museo Britannico asservati suo sumptu incidendas curavit Soc. Antiquar. Londin. A.D. MDCCCIII" in Vetusta Monumenta vol. 4 plates 5–7</ref> The first detailed account of the medieval French [[Royal Gold Cup]] in the [[British Museum]] was published in one of the last papers, of 1904, by Sir [[Charles Hercules Read]].<ref>Read, Sir Charles Hercules. ''The Royal Gold Cup of the Kings of France and England, now preserved in the British Museum''. ''Vetusta Monumenta'' Volume 7, part 3, 1904</ref>
==Contributors== The following is an incomplete list of noted contributors, and their articles:<!-- eg. the DNB, 1900 --> * [[Thomas Astle]] * [[Thomas Amyot]], a description of [[Tewkesbury Abbey]] * [[William Wilkins (architect)|William Wilkins]], 'Observations on the Porta Honoris of Caius College, Cambridge' * [[George Gwilt the Younger]], architect * [[Browne Willis]], 'A Table of the Gold Coins of the Kings of England.' (1733)<ref name="Chalmers1817">{{cite book|last=Chalmers|first=Alexander|title=The General biographical dictionary: containing an historical and critical account of the lives and writings of the most eminent persons in every nation: particularly the British and Irish; from the earliest accounts to the present time|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qW1kAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA144|accessdate=24 November 2010|volume=32|year=1817|publisher=Printed for J. Nichols|pages=143–4|chapter=Willis, Browne}}</ref> *[[Thomas Walford]] (iii. pt. 39)<ref name=DNB00>{{cite DNB|wstitle =Walford, Thomas|first =Edward Irving |last = Carlyle |authorlink =Edward Irving Carlyle|volume=59}}</ref>
Notices on illustrations mention the following engravers: * [[George Vertue]], engraver to the society. Produced a drawing of the [[Holbein Gate]] in 1724, his 1727 engraving appears in volume 1, 1747.<ref>'[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=67926 The Holbein Gate and the Tiltyard Gallery]', Survey of London: volume 14: St Margaret, Westminster, part III: Whitehall II (1931), pp. 10-22. Date accessed: 24 November 2010.</ref> Other works include the portrait of Richard II at Westminster, the shrine of Edward the Confessor, and a view of [[Waltham Cross]]; nearly all the copperplate to 1756 was engraved by Vertue.<ref name=DNB1>{{cite DNB|wstitle=Vertue, George|last=O'Donoghue|first=Freeman Marius|authorlink=Freeman Marius O'Donoghue}}</ref> * [[James Basire]] (1730–1802), one of Vertue's successors, who produced large and exquisite design on copperplate. His descendants of the same name, the son James Basire (1769–1822) and grandson (1796–1869), were also appointed engraver of the Society. His work for the volumes—after his appointment in the 1760s—is described as amongst his best,<ref>{{cite DNB|title=Basire, James, et al.}} citing Redgrave, ''Dict''.</ref> however, * [[William Blake]], Basire's apprentice is thought to be partly, if not largely, responsible for many of the designs.<ref name="Wright2003">{{cite book|last=Wright|first=Thomas|title=Life of William Blake|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CdFWtiMjVzgC&pg=PA4|accessdate=24 November 2010|date=2003-02-01|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-7661-2852-1|page=4}}</ref> * [[Charles Alfred Stothard]], coloured facsimile of the [[Bayeux Tapestry]] in 1818<ref>'The Bayeux Tapestry' in Encyclopædia Britannica, 1911.<!-- unverified, needs checking --></ref> * [[Jacob Schnebbelie]] (d. 1826), draughtsman to the society. Executed many of the architectural views of the second and third volumes.<ref name="Hone1832">{{cite book|last=Hone|first=William|title=The year book of daily recreation and information|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=brIPAAAAQAAJ&pg=RA1-PA25|accessdate=23 November 2010|year=1832|publisher=[[Thomas Tegg]]|pages=219–20}}</ref> * [[Samuel Hieronymous Grimm]]
==References== {{Reflist|}}
==Further reading== *Grazia Lolla, Maria. ''Ceci n'est pas un monument: Vetusta Monumenta and antiquarian aesthetics'', in ''Producing the Past: Aspects of Antiquarian Culture and Practice, 1700-1850'', eds Martin Myrone and Lucy Peltz, 1999, Ashgate

{{Unreferenced|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} A '''women's interest channel''' generally refers to either a [[television station]], [[television network|network]] or [[specialty channel]] that targets women as its main [[demographic]]; offering programs that will appeal to the female population.
There are two types of female interest channels: ''general interest'' and ''niche interest''.
==General interest== General interest women's channels are television channels that contain programming from various categories and genres that will appeal to the female population including films, lifestyle series, dramatic series, reality series, and talk shows on varying topics including cooking, travel, cars, sex, and sports.
===Examples of general interest female channels=== * [[2nd Avenue (television channel)|2nd Avenue]] (Philippines) * [[9Gem]] (Australia) * [[Big CBS Love]] (India, defunct) * [[Cooking Channel (Canada)|Cooking Channel]] - formerly W Movies and SexTV: The Channel (Canada) * [[Cosmopolitan Television]] (Latin America) * [[Cosmopolitan TV (Canada)|Cosmopolitan TV]] (Canada) * [[Diva Universal]] (Asia) * [[Divinity (TV channel)|Divinity]] (Spain) * [[Escape (TV network)|Escape]] (USA) * [[Estil 9]] (Catalonia) * [[ETC (Philippine TV channel)|ETC]] (Philippines) * [[Eve (TV channel)|Eve]] (Southeast Asia) * [[La5]] (Italy) * [[Lifestyle (Philippine TV channel)|Lifestyle]] (Philippines) * [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] (USA) * [[Living (channel)|Living]] (UK) * [[MOI&cie (TV channel)|MOI&cie]] (Canada) * [[Mya (TV channel)|Mya]] (Italy) * [[Nova (TV channel)|Nova]] (Spain) * [[Nueve (Spanish TV channel)|Nueve]] (Spain) * [[Oprah Winfrey Network (Canadian TV channel)|OWN]] (Canada) * [[Oxygen (TV channel)|Oxygen]] (USA) * [[Passion (TV channel)|Passion]] (Germany) * [[Q (TV network)|Q]] (Philippines, defunct) * [[RTL 8]] (Netherlands) * [[RTL Passion]] * [[SIC Mulher]] (Portugal) * [[Sixx]] (Germany) * [[Slice (TV channel)|Slice]] (Canada) * [[SoHo (Australian TV channel)|SoHo]] (Australia) * [[Sony Channel (Asia)|Sony Channel]] (Southeast Asia) * [[STAR World]] (Asia) * [[Star World Philippines|StarWorld]] (Philippines) * [[Téva]] (France) * [[Twist TV]] (Canada) * [[Velvet (TV channel)|Velvet]] (Philippines, defunct) * [[VH1]] (USA) * [[W Network]] (Canada) * [[WE tv]] (USA)
==Niche interest== Niche interest women's channels are television channels that contain programming with a specific television genre such as film channels, and lifestyle channels.
===Examples of women's interest niche channels=== * [[Lifetime (Canada)|Lifetime]] (Canada) * [[LMN (TV network)|LMN]] (USA) * [[W Movies]] (Canada)
